page.title: 09TREES AT POLWARTH 2
page.content: OTHER TREES TO BE FOUND INCLUDE ELM (SOME AFFECTED BY DUTCH ELM DISEASE), HORNBEAM, OAK, THE MARCHMONT OAK IN 1962 HOLDING THE TITLE IN THE GUINESS BOOK OF RECORDS OF THE TALLEST IN BRITAIN, BIRCH, LIME, ASH, ALDER,GEAN, HAZEL & WILLOW. SPECIALLY BROUGHT IN ARE 2 HUGE SILVER FIRS IN FRONT OF MARCHMONT & A WELLINGTONIA, ARBUTUS & FERN LEAVED BEECH IN THE GARDEN.THERE RE MANY RHODODENDRONS, PONTICUM & SPECIES. FRUIT TREES GROW WELL & CRAB APPLES MAKE FINE JELLY. PLUMS CAN DO WELL & SOFT FRUIT, PARTICULARLY RASPBERRIES WHICH GROW IN THE WILD. BLAEBERRIES ARE TO BE FOUND & BRAMBLES & SLOES. ELDERS ARE EVERYWHERE & THE FLOWERS ARE PICKED TO MAKE A VERY DELECTABLE SUMMER CORDIAL. THIS IS NOT HOWEVER THE BEST APPLE GROWING AREA.
